item.title: Trump Call With Putin Underway as US Seeks Ukraine Ceasefire
item.description: US President Donald Trump began a phone call with Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin on Monday, aiming to secure a ceasefire in the war in Ukraine that Moscow has shown no sign of accepting.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin, Donald Trump

item.title: China Accuses US of Undermining Geneva Trade Talks With Huawei Stance
item.description: The Chinese government accused the Trump administration of undermining recent trade talks in Geneva with its warning that using Huawei Technologies Co.’s artificial-intelligence chips “anywhere in the world” would violate US export controls.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Tam, Debby Wu

media:content.media:description: A corporate logo sits on a Huawei Technologies Co. NetEngine 8000 intelligent metro router on display during a 5G event in London, U.K., on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2020. Huawei said at the event it currently has 91 contracts for 5G, with 47 of those in Europe.

item.title: Tusk Faces Crunch Two Weeks to Fend Off Polish Nationalists
item.description: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk and his allies have less than two weeks to convince voters to stick with their ruling coalition after a surge in support for nationalists in a presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Skolimowski, Natalia Ojewska

media:content.media:description: Poland's Prime Minister Donald Tusk talks to the press after a meeting during the European Political Community (EPC) summit, in Tirana on May 16, 2025. (Photo by Leon Neal / POOL / AFP) (Photo by LEON NEAL/POOL/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: UK Plans New Powers to Tackle Rise in Iran-Backed Threats
item.description: Britain plans to strengthen its ability to crack down on state-backed terrorist threats following an increase in security incidents involving Iranian nationals in the UK, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: Iranians protesting against the Islamic republic outside the Houses of Parliament in London on May 4, 2025.

item.title: Solar Shares Fall as GOP Targets Earlier End to Tax Credits
item.description: Shares of solar companies slumped after conservative Republican lawmakers said they had secured a commitment from leadership to end key clean-energy tax credits earlier than planned, part of a sweeping deal aimed at allowing President Donald Trump’s giant tax and spending package to advance.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter, Will Wade

media:content.media:description: Contractors install SunRun Inc. solar panels on the roof of a new home at the Westline Homes Willowood Cottages community in Sacramento, California, U.S., on Wednesday, Aug. 15, 2018. California is the first state in the U.S. to require solar panels on almost all new homes as part of a mandate to take effect in 2020.

item.title: Denmark Offers Aid for Wind Investments After Failed Auction
item.description: Denmark is offering 27.6 billion Danish kroner ($4.2 billion) in state aid to ensure more investments in offshore wind as the Nordic country attempts to reignite interest after a recent failure of a government tender.
item.dc:creator: Christian Wienberg

media:content.media:description: Offshore wind turbines at the Middelgrunden wind farm off the coast of Copenhagen, Denmark, on Thursday, Jan. 26, 2023. The wind farm off the coast of Denmark gives tour groups the rare opportunity to actually climb a turbine.

item.title: Trump Attacks South Africa Before Ramaphosa Visit
item.description: US President Donald Trump for the second time in a week accused South Africa of perpetrating a genocide against White people — without any proof — just days before he is set to receive the country’s leader, Cyril Ramaphosa, in the White House.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian, Neil Munshi

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks to members of media on Air Force One on May 15.

item.title: Starmer’s Reset Hailed by EU Chiefs, Slammed by UK Conservatives
item.description: Keir Starmer sealed an agreement with European Union leaders that lays the ground for closer collaboration with the bloc, while revealing the political peril to Britain’s Prime Minister of revisiting the terms of Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Alex Wickham, Jorge Valero, Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Antonio Costa, left, Keir Starmer, and Ursula von der Leyen on May 19. Photographer: Carl Court/Getty Images

item.title: CBS News Chief McMahon Quits Over Disagreement With Management
item.description: Wendy McMahon, who served as chief executive officer of CBS News and its station group, said she is stepping down, citing a disagreement with management.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miller

media:content.media:description: Wendy McMahon Photographer: Michele Crowe/CBS/Getty Images

item.title: Why Poland’s Election Is a Barometer for Europe’s Populist Wave
item.description: Poland’s presidential election will determine whether the country can restore the rule of law and remain a reliable partner in the European Union after nearly a decade of divisive right-wing populism.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Skolimowski, Wojciech Moskwa

media:content.media:description: Supporters of Rafal Trzaskowski at an election rally in the Main Square in Krakow, Poland, on May 13, 2025. Photographer: Jakub Porzycki/Anadolu/Getty Images

item.title: Netanyahu Says Israel to Take Over All Gaza, Start Aid Flows
item.description: Israel will take over the entire Gaza Strip, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Monday, as the military announced it would carry out an “unprecedented attack” on Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Odenheimer, Ethan Bronner, Galit Altstein

item.title: Lutnick Divests Cantor Fitzgerald to His Children, 26North
item.description: US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick sold his stakes in the Wall Street business group he ran for more than three decades, passing ownership to his children and private outside investors and cashing out at least hundreds of millions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Todd Gillespie

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick

item.title: Trump Invites Pope Leo to Visit White House
item.description: US President Donald Trump invited Pope Leo XIV, the first American pontiff, to visit him in Washington, the White House said Monday.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Pope Leo XIV waves to the crowd as he arrives in the Popemobile for his inaugural mass in St. Peter's Square in Vatican City, Italy, on Sunday, May 18, 2025. US Vice President JD Vance and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy met for the first time since their White House spat, smiling and shaking hands at the Vatican on Sunday as the Holy See celebrated the enthronement of Pope Leo XIV.

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Advances After Deal for Faster Medicaid Cuts
item.description: A key House committee advanced President Donald Trump’s giant tax and spending package after Republican hardliners won agreement from party leaders to speed up cuts to Medicaid health coverage.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Jarrell Dillard, Steven T. Dennis, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI

item.title: Romania Will Need to Move Quickly on Reforms, Finance Chief Says
item.description: Romania’s finance chief said a new government will need to move quickly to fix state finances even after the election of Bucharest Mayor Nicusor Dan as president helped soothe market turmoil that’s engulfed the Black Sea nation.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: Barna Tanczos Photographer: Ioana Moldovan/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Aide Hassett Dismisses Moody’s Downgrade, Calls US Debt ‘Safest Bet’
item.description: White House National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett criticized Moody’s Ratings over its decision to lower the US credit rating, calling the move backward-looking and saying the Trump administration is committed to lowering federal spending.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Kevin Hassett, director of the National Economic Council, speaks to members of the media outside the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, April 18, 2025. Donald Trump is studying whether he’s able to fire Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, Hassett said Friday, a day after the president publicly criticized the head of the central bank for not moving fast enough to slash interest rates.

item.title: India Readies Gas Power Fleet to Prevent Summer Blackouts
item.description: India has invoked emergency measures that require gas-fired power stations to produce more in order to ensure uninterrupted electricity supply during the summer season, as soaring temperatures boost demand.
item.dc:creator: Rajesh Kumar Singh, Rakesh Sharma

media:content.media:description: A gas-fired power station in Delhi, India. Photographer: Udit Kulshrestha

item.title: Chile Poll Shows Evelyn Matthei and Jose Antonio Kast Tied in Race for Presidency
item.description: Chile ultra conservative candidate Jose Antonio Kast tied center-right contender Evelyn Matthei atop a new presidential poll, marking the latest twist in the race to lead one of Latin America’s richest economies.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Jose Antonio Kast, left, and Evelyn Matthei. Source: Bloomberg, AFP/Getty Images/AFP

item.title: Sudan Army Chief Names First Prime Minister Since War Erupted
item.description: Sudan’s army chief named the country’s first prime minister since the eruption of a brutal two-year civil war.
item.dc:creator: Mohammed Alamin

item.title: Taiwan’s Lai Toughens China Stance, Stoking Debate on Democracy
item.description: As President Lai Ching-te approaches his first year in office, he’s sending a stark warning to the people of Taiwan: If you say anything that threatens the archipelago’s security, there will be consequences.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Cindy Wang, Miaojung Lin

item.title: France Touts Record Foreign Investment at Macron’s Summit
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron will tally more than €40 billion ($45.1 billion) in foreign investment at an annual gathering with business leaders, seeking to send an upbeat message as the slow-growing economy faces headwinds from US trade tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Tara Patel, William Horobin, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron

item.title: Rheinmetall in Talks With Latvia on Manufacturing Arms Locally
item.description: The Latvian government is in talks with German weapons manufacturer Rheinmetall AG on producing defense equipment domestically as part of an effort by Baltic nations to bolster their military capabilities in the face of Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Eglitis, Donato Paolo Mancini, Arne Delfs

media:content.media:description: A mobile air defense system at the Rheinmetall stand during the FEINDEF defense exhibition in Madrid in May.

item.title: EU’s €150 Billion Defense Fund Receives Preliminary Approval
item.description: The European Union’s 27 member states gave initial approval to a €150 billion ($169 billion) defense fund that will distribute money to countries looking to invest in security capabilities such as ammunition, drones and the protection of critical infrastructure, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Caesar self-propelled howitzer cannon assembly at a factory in France.

item.title: Germany Says Working on New Russia Sanctions in Ceasefire Push
item.description: Germany is working with allies on a new package of sanctions aimed at pressuring Russia to agree to a ceasefire in its war with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: Burned out vehicles outside a shopping mall following a Russian drone attack on Kyiv, on May 4 Photographer: Sergei Supinsky/Getty Images

item.title: China Gave Pakistan Satellite Help, India Defense Group Says
item.description: China provided Pakistan with air defense and satellite support during its clash with India this month, according to a research group under India’s Ministry of Defence, suggesting that Beijing was more directly involved in the conflict than was previously disclosed.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen, Dan Strumpf

media:content.media:description: A motorcyclist rides past shattered glasses of a restaurant outside the Rawalpindi cricket stadium after an alleged drone was shot down in Rawalpindi on May 8, 2025. India and Pakistan accused each other on May 8 of carrying out waves of drone attacks, as deadly confrontations between the nuclear-armed foes drew global calls for calm. Pakistan's army said it shot down 25 Indian drones, while New Delhi accused Islamabad of launching overnight raids with "drones and missiles", and claimed it destroyed an air defence system in Lahore. (Photo by Aamir QURESHI / AFP) (Photo by AAMIR QURESHI/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Romanian Centrist Beats Far-Right, Tusk Ally Ahead in Poland
item.description: Romania’s presidential election saw the centrist mayor of Bucharest defeat a far-right Donald Trump loyalist, while a nationalist finished a close second in Poland to set up a tight runoff on June 1.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: Nicusor Dan greets supporters following the first exit poll results, at an election night rally in Bucharest, Romania, on May 18, 2025. Photographer: Andrei Pungovschi/Getty Images

item.title: Three Votes and No Easy Way Forward for Europe
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Alan Crawford

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski, mayor of Warsaw, center left, and his wife Malgorzata Trzaskowski during an election night rally in Sandomierz, Poland, on Sunday, May 18, 2025. Trzaskowski, the centrist Warsaw mayor, and Karol Nawrocki, a pro-Donald Trump nationalist, came neck-and-neck in the first round of Poland's presidential election, according to an exit poll, in a blow to the pro-European government. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: Iran Says Its Uranium Enrichment Is ‘Absolutely Non-Negotiable’
item.description: Iran said its ability to enrich uranium was “absolutely non-negotiable” after US President Donald Trump’s special envoy repeated a demand that the Islamic Republic cease its production of the fissile material.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: Technicians work inside a uranium conversion facility outside Isfahan, Iran. Photographer: Getty Images/Getty Images

item.title: Marcos Says He Is Open to Reconcile With the Duterte Family
item.description: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. said he’s willing to mend ties with the family of Vice President Sara Duterte, after candidates supported by his estranged deputy won more seats than expected during last week’s Senate election.
item.dc:creator: Cliff Harvey Venzon

media:content.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. during a campaign event in Manila on May 9.

item.title: Tanzania Opposition Says Democracy at Risk as Leader Faces Trial
item.description: Tanzania’s main opposition leader is facing treason charges months before presidential elections, a case that has heightened concerns about the state of democracy in the East African nation.
item.dc:creator: Helen Nyambura

media:content.media:description: Tundu Lissu speaks with his lawyers at the magistrate’s court in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.
